column1: Gastrin is the main hormone that controls the release of acid in your stomach.
Too much gastrin causes severe peptic ulcer disease.

A higher than normal level may also be due to: - Chronic kidney disease - Long-term gastritis - Over-activity of the gastrin-producing cells in the stomach (G-cell hyperplasia) - Helicobacter pylori infection of the stomach - Use of antacids or medicines to treat heartburn - Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, a gastrin-producing tumor that may develop in the stomach or pancreas
